DOC.HEAD: As Shooting Dies Down, Revolution Death Toll Still Unknown
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after the revolution broke out, there still is no official word on how many people died in street fighting throughout Romania. Estimates range from hundreds to several tens of thousands. As the first sketchy witness accounts began to trickle out of the western city of Timisoara where the uprising began, the death toll was first estimated at hundreds, then thousands. Then the revolution spread to other areas in Transylvania and finally to the capital, Bucharest. As fighting escalated in the streets with security forces loyal to Nicolae Ceausescu battling the army and young revolutionaries, the estimates of dead rose. At one point a report set the number at up to 70,000. But only days later, French health officials were told about 700 had died. Initial reports from witnesses and citizens in Timisoara, where security forces opened fire on unarmed demonstrators Dec. 17, set the death toll in the hundreds, then appeared to concur in estimates of between 2,000 and 4,500. At one point, there were estimates that 12,000 people were killed in Timisoara, more than 7,000 of them reportedly executed by the security forces after being detained. But Western journalists returning from Timisoara and other cities in the region where heavy fighting had been reported said they doubted those figures, and thought the total likely would turn out to be much lower. On Dec. 22, the day Ceausescu was toppled and tried to escape the capital by helicopter from the roof of his palace, U.S. diplomats said they saw 13 killed in Bucharest. But East European news agencies reporting out of Bucharest before Western reporters were able to enter the country said hundreds had died. The following day, Dr. Marian Palaschivescu said he alone had counted 54 bodies, and an Austrian pilot said he counted 30 bodies at the airport after fierce fighting on Dec. 24. Ninety bodies were counted that day at only one of many morgues in the city. The East German news agency ADN reported that the National Salvation Committee seeking to run the country estimated that 5,000 were killed in only two days of fighting. On Christmas day, Hungarian radio cited ``authoritative sources'' as saying some 70,000 had died and 300,000 were injured. But Victor Ciobanu, the health minister under Ceausescu now supporting the provisional government, said that day that 500 had died in Bucharest over the previous four days of fighting. The day after Christmas, Romanians in Bucharest began preparing to bury their dead, and 200 freshly dug graves were counted in one cemetery. French health officials were told this week that 746 people had died in the revolution, but Western diplomats estimated from witness accounts and their own assessments that some 10,000 people had died.
